qas.question: Where was the band Blue Cheer from?
What classic song did Blue Cheer cover?
What was the hit off Steppenwolf's self-titled debut lp?
What movie featured that Steppenwolf single?
The lyrics to "Born To Be Wild" contain the first reference to what hard rock style?
What Blue Cheer classic was duplicated by Eddie Cochran?
What song was not included in the 1968 debut album Vincebus Eruptum?
What LA based band released a distorted cover of Summertime Blues?
When did Vanilla Fudge release Born to be Wild?
What song was used in the film Easy Rider in 1965?

context: Groups that emerged from the American psychedelic scene about the same time included Iron Butterfly, MC5, Blue Cheer and Vanilla Fudge. <a0_0>San Francisco<a0_0/> band <b7_0>Blue Cheer<b7_0/> released a crude and distorted cover of Eddie Cochran's classic <a1_0>"<b5_0><b6_0>Summertime Blues<b6_0/><b5_0/>"<a1_0/>, from their <b8_0>1968<b8_0/> debut album Vincebus Eruptum, that outlined much of the later hard rock and heavy metal sound. The same month, Steppenwolf released its self-titled debut album, including <a2_0>"<b9_0>Born to Be Wild<b9_0/>"<a2_0/>, which contained the first lyrical reference to <a4_0>heavy metal<a4_0/> and helped popularise the style when it was used in the film <a3_0>Easy Rider<a3_0/> (1969). Iron Butterfly's In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida (1968), with its 17-minute-long title track, using organs and with a lengthy drum solo, also prefigured later elements of the sound.
